ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Developed a greater understanding of how different market actors initiate the shift from centralized to free market economies. Learnt a lot about historical economic trajectories of several post-communist countries.
A better understanding of the relationship between businesses and governments in a variety of different contexts. A better understanding of the field of comparative politics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I liked how the course hit such a wide variety of topics. While some of the guest lecturers were good, I actually would have rather had Shapiro teach all the classes because he's a great lecturer.

Really enjoyed writing my responses for the take-home midterm and final - felt I learnt a lot through this process and it is generally a far better way to test than setting in class exams that are often rushed and don't allow for thorough exploration of the material.

The guest lectures were really good and Professor Shapiro placed a lot of emphasis on bringing outside experts which was great. I think a smaller class size would be able to better stimulate discussion

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Good class, a little dry at times, but the material is worthwhile. Shapiro is a great lecturer.
Yes, very interesting course and you will gain a lot of knowledge. Shapiro is an excellent Professor and he brings in great guest speakers from all across a range of disciplines.
Yes for the interesting course material and if youre looking for a small and laid back lecture class. Definitely not like a seminar in its format.
